newsitem.title: UK: Key points from 1994 and 1995 UK budgets.
newsitem.headline: Key points from 1994 and 1995 UK budgets.

text.p: Following is a summary of key points from the 1995 and 1994 UK budgets, as compiled by the Treasury.
Chancellor of the Exchequer Kenneth Clarke will present his 1997/98 budget, the last before the next general election, on November 26.
- 3-1/4 billion pounds reduction in 1996-97 spending plans
1.3 billion pounds extra current spending for NHS
878 million pounds extra next year for schools
- Better public services delivered in new partnerships with the private sector
- Campaign against tax and social security fraud
- Nearly 2 billion pounds a year cut in real terms in the cost of running Government by 1998-99
- 3-1/4 billion pounds cut in taxes in 1996-97
- Three steps towards target of 20p basic rate:
basic rate of income tax cut by 1p
tax on savings income cut to 20p
- Higher rate threshold increased by 1,200 pounds
- Married couple's allowance and income limit for age-related allowances indexed
- Small companies' corporation tax cut by 1p to 24p
- More help for businesses on rates bills
- 500 million pounds cut in employers' national insurance contributions
- Inheritance tax threshold up to 200,000 pounds
- Measures to help elderly with costs of long term care
- Mortgage protection and long-term care insurance benefits exempt from tax
- 12p off a bottle of fortified wine
- no change for beer, wine and most cider
- 8p a pint on very strong cider
- 6 per cent cut in pools betting duty
- 1 per cent cut in general betting duty
- 3.5p a litre on petrol and diesel
- 7.4p a litre on super unleaded petrol
- 15 per cent cut in duty on road fuel gases
Higher rate - 40 per cent over 24,300 over 25,500
CGT and IHT CGT annual exempt amount (pounds):
Change since 1994 Budget after classification changes
(Percentage change on year earlier unless otherwise stated)
NOTE: RPIX is underlying inflation. PSBR is public sector borrowing requirement (budget deficit) and figures are for financial year to April 5.
Cash plans for Control Total down by 24 billion for years 1995-96 to 1997-98 compared with figures in last Budget.
- Personal allowances for 65s and over raised 430;
- Spirits, beer, cider and most wines unchanged
- Vehicle excise duty up 5 to 135 for cars, light vans.
- Value added tax (VAT): Standard rate unchanged at 17-1/2 per cent; will apply to domestic fuel and power from 1 April 1995.
- Employers' national insurance contributions (NICs): rates for employees earning less than 205 a week cut by 0.6 per cent;

Business rates: transitional relief worth over 600 million following April 1995 revaluation - real increases in rates bills limited to 7 1/2 per cent a year for small properties; 10 per cent for large properties.
Venture Capital Trusts: will provide income tax relief at 20 per cent, and capital gains tax reinvestment relief on investments up to 100,000 a year in mainly unquoted trading companies.
Enterprise Investment Scheme: capital gains tax reinvestment relief extended to investments in EIS.
